questions.question_text: Which statement is correct regarding LDAP authentication using the regular bind type?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Regular bind uses 4 steps.

Selected Answer: A
See page 163 of the Network Security Support Engineer Study Guide: There are four steps to LDAP authentication using regular bind.

Regular bind is the most complex, versatile and commonly used method. So it is NOT the easiest type. Therefore, answer A is correct.

choices.D: The regular bind type requires a FortiGate super_admin account.
choices.A: The regular bind type goes through four steps to successfully authenticate a user.
choices.C: The regular bind type is the easiest bind type to configure on FortiOS.
choices.B: The regular bind type cannot be used if users are authenticated using sAMAccountName.

choices.D: The total slab size of the ip_session slab is 3600 kB and is associated with the user space.
choices.A: The total slab size of the tcp_session slab is 7500 kB and is associated with the kernel.
choices.B: The total slab size of the ip6_session slab is 1300 kB and is associated with the kernel.
choices.C: The total slab size of the sctp_session slab is 0 kB and is associated with the user space.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
2nd column represents available objects, multiplied by object size it gives you the total slab size, in tcp_session case 5x1500=7500 A is correct

choices.A: This is an expected session created by the IPS engine.
choices.C: Traffic in the original direction (coming from the IP address 10.171.121.38) will be routed to the next-hop IP address 10.200.1.1.
choices.D: This is a pinhole session created to allow traffic for a protocol that requires additional sessions to operate through FortiGate.
choices.B: Traffic in the original direction (coming from the IP address 10.171.121.38) will be routed to the next-hop IP address 10.0.1.10.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
*wouldn't be showing up

Selected Answer: BD
BD are correct, this is a pinhole session otherwise it would be showing up with the executed CLI command.

questions.question_text: Which of the following regarding protocol states is true?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Troubleshooting-Tip-FortiGate-session-table-information/ta-p/196988
Correct answer is B.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct 7.4 study guide page 85

choices.A: proto_state=00 indicates that UDP traffic flows in both directions.
choices.C: proto_state=10 indicates an established TCP session.
choices.B: proto_state=01 indicates an established TCP session.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
Correct answer is AB.

https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Troubleshooting-Tip-How-to-troubleshoot-FSSO-agentless-polling/ta-p/214349

From the snippet we can see that FortiGate (via the fssod daemon) is directly detecting the user logon rather than relying on a separate “collector” or “DC agent.” This indicates agentless polling—FortiGate polls the DC’s event logs over TCP 445 to discover logons. So:
- FSSO is using agentless polling mode to detect logon events (Choice A).
- In agentless mode, FortiGate will periodically poll the same IP (the DC) on port 445 to see if the user is still logged on (Choice B).

Choices C and D imply that a collector/DC agent is installed on the domain controller (which is not the case in agentless polling), so they do not apply.

Selected Answer: AB
AB are correct this output corresponds with agentless polling mode, in which FortiGate polls all workstations on port 445 to verify if the user is still logged in.

choices.D: FSSO is using DC agent mode to detect logon events.
choices.B: The workstation with IP 10.124.2.90 will be polled frequently using TCP port 445 to see if the user is still logged on.
choices.A: FSSO is using agentless polling mode to detect logon events.
choices.C: The logon event can be seen on the collector agent installed on Windows.
